content: Lost and Struggling Students: What should you do with your life? Some tips and hope for you… Pascal Bedard Blocked Unblock Follow Following Jul 2, 2017 I see lots of “lost students” and many try to get guidance and help. I personally had many major life changes and made very hard choices in my life, and I helped a LOT of people and students change their lives quite dramatically. Some students “land” in university by default: they know they don’t want a minimum wage job forever, and they don’t see job options without a degree, so they “go to university” just because there are no clear options and they spend 3, 4, 5 years studying and hoping that things will clarify along the way. Image from /2ufkI3h The cycle of doom We can “categorize” people in many ways and certainly many shades of grey exist, but I tend to “classify” students in 3 broad categories based on my experience: The ones who find something that makes them interested and curious enough to envision a job in that “sector.” Their vision for their life gives them drive, as they feel some purpose to what they are doing. They find self discipline, personal organization, curiosity, and energy, and they move on to fruitful studies, jobs, and lives. The ones who don’t care much about anything , but “cave into” reality: they accept that you gotta work and you can’t avoid it forever, and so they “do OK” but have many ups and downs and they can’t seem to find the drive and motivation that comes with a clear vision and purpose, so they have issues with regularity, self-discipline, follow-through, and recurring bouts of negative thoughts and feelings. The lost . They don’t really see themselves in anything “mainstream” and they can’t find the courage to “suck it up and work.” They are in denial and avoidance of reality, they find little interest in courses (but some may still perform very well), they ask “is this useful”, they may struggle in their courses and in their intimate relationships and friendships (which are often with other “lost individuals” who are less confronting for them, as they are just as lost as they are), and they suffer ongoing anxiety, inner turmoil, fear, and self-worth issues. They either get “official” anti depressants (rarely) OR they self-medicate with alcohol, drugs, sex, food, Netflix and social media binging, drama and instability, lots of “partying and social life” — anything that helps them escape the harsh reality of the income-jobs-and-responsibilities world. From my extensive university teaching experience, I would say that the split is roughly balanced between these 3 groups, each representing about a third of all students. The ones in the first group generally do well and, more importantly, end up happy and positive young adults, with the normal ups and downs of life. Others remain as lost as ever, and even more… and the anxiety increases as the end of the program approaches, because they don’t want to work in an office, they don’t see themselves anywhere, they don’t like technical stuff, and yet they gradually have no choice but to face reality: they need income and they can’t live off of mom and dad or student loans forever! They face “the question” with growing intensity. The post-bachelor’s degree blues sets in. The party is over. The freedom of managing your time essentially as you want is over (except for the 12 to 18 hours of actual class time, which they often skipped). The “real world.” Many have deep or minor depressions. The question… “What the hell should I do with my life?” Friends go on to various lives, realities, cities, and jobs, and the joy and magic of “student togetherness” withers away as time goes by. Because we all need income to live life, pay mortgage / rent, food, travel, and so much more, many university grads find themselves ending university and faced with a harsh reality they were able to deny for their teens and during the roommate and Uni years : if you don’t get income from parents or the State or a spouse, you gotta work to get some… They enter a phase of existential crisis, as the years of avoidance near the end. Some go to graduate programs in master’s and phd, others don’t want to or don’t have the grades, yet they don’t seem to find a “spot to fit in” in terms of jobs. They feel alone, lost, and without a place in the world. And so it goes. The positive ones who found a “study and career path” they feel motivated about move forward, while the ones who feel lost have deepening problems of anxiety and self worth. Some have parents that support them financially, which helps with the “real world” aspects of life (paying bills and stuff), but it does little in the way of bringing a sense of purpose and direction in life, which is key to some form of inner peace and life satisfaction. The lost ones who have external financing even have another problem: they don’t even “have to” move their ass to work and do “something” with their time, so they risk stagnation and inertia, which breed anxiety and more inertia, self worth, and self-discipline issues. The initial lack of drive and motivation turns into an ingrained behavioural pattern, and the person launches into post-university life with a lack of drive, a lack purpose and vision, and increasing issues of inertia, laziness, and procrastination. Their self-worth sinks lower, which reinforces the inertia and lack of action that would pull them out of the rut. It can be a dark place. Getting out of the rut This rut is not specific to students and recent grads. Many people find themselves in such dynamics at one point or another between the start and the end of that great adventure we call life. Here are a few things you need to do to pull yourself out of that dark place… Face reality You must kill all forms of bullshit you are telling yourself and look at life and the world as they are, including yourself. “The system” may be imperfect and suck (I agree), but it is what it is and you won’t change it in any significant “macro way”, nor will I. You need to “do something” with your life, EVEN if you are financially supported. It is even more true if you have no significant external financial support. Autonomy and personal growth and key to self worth and life satisfaction. This means you need to “move your ass” and do something other than social network surfing, video games, Netflix binging, and TV. Use your time to do things that make you learn and grow. In other words, you need to find “flow” in your life. This can be art, sports, working out, “causes”, whatever, but it has to be something that pulls you sufficiently to get you out of inertia. You also need to be nice with yourself and quit the inner dialogue about being a loser, as this will simply create what you are telling yourself, without being true. Also admit that life is not all rosy and fun, that boredom is very frequent and normal, that jobs are often not great, etc. You need to be nice with yourself but you must also stop feeling sorry for yourself . Endless spinning on how jobs suck, how boring they are, how people are stupid, what you should of / could of / would have done is useless and perpetuates the layer of denial and illusion (i.e. bullshit) that are stopping you from becoming a more active and emotionally positive person that is lucid about what is and what can be done going forward. Know yourself This is a biggie and could be worth a whole book! You have to free yourself of the illusions imposed by yourself, family, or “society” about success and a meaningful life. I am personally a bit fed up with blog posts on “productivity” and “achievement” and all that pop psy stuff. Not that it’s not true or useful — it is. But before you start to attack your issues of lack of drive and direction, you need to get clear on what you want and what you don’t, what you can and what you can’t realistically do. Once you have a clear and bs-free picture of who you are, THEN you will gradually be able to look into becoming “productive and creative” and all that great stuff. If you don’t want to work in the corporate world, relax, it’s FINE — many people are like that, including most of your profs! You must get clear on 1) who you are, 2) what you can “reasonably tolerate” in a job or occupation (there are always cons — not just “pros”), what you can’t do or tolerate due to personality, attention span, personal initiative, risk tolerance, and more. This must be an all-around and deep introspection into your basic tendencies, talents, natural interests, strengths, and weaknesses. It is very important that this picture be done with brutal honesty, so avoid asking friends who always avoid tough or awkward discussions. There is NO “wrong” picture of who you are, but don’t forget that you can’t simply come to the conclusion that you don’t want to work or do anything, unless you have infinite financial support, but EVEN THEN I very strongly suggest you do “something” with your life, because you will end up miserable, bored, and the endless freedom and leisure will start to feel hollow as the years go by… Explore income opportunities Explore ALL possibilities. Look at all titles of the BLS jobs list and imagine what it’s like. Then expand your imagination into jobs, occupations, and careers that may not be there. There are lots. You can reinvent yourself totally many times, at ANY age. I did it and so can you. Don’t forget that you want to do “something” with your time and your life. If you don’t need money, then explore what you can do that would bring “meaning” to your weeks and months. The possibilities are endless and they need not involve helping others. Just explore what you feel good about when you visualize that “life setup” as vividly and realistically as possible. Some people like to climb full time, others like to work like crazy — it’s all fine, as long as it aligns at least in large part with what you “are” fundamentally and a life that brings meaning to your days and makes you get out of bed. Match income opportunities with who you are (as much as possible) Once you have done proper introspection and explored the opportunities for income and occupations, try to match the realities of yourself (talents, strengths, weaknesses, etc) with the jobs or occupations. For example, if you value income and job security, don’t look into self employment. If you can’t develop self discipline and personal initiative, perhaps it will be hard to do projects on your own, so keep it in mind. Again, don’t overdo it: NO occupation or job is totally “perfect”! Most people “suck it up” at least a bit, and that’s ok, it’s called reality. Just avoid landing in a life and job path that is totally disconnected from who you are, because you will be miserable and will probably suffer mentally (depression) or physically due to psychosomatic symptoms, or both. Even if I gave you 1 million dollars per year to chill out, you would eventually find it lacking purpose, because humans seek meaning from this crazy world and mysterious life. You must find a “reasonable” compromise between your personality and general characteristics and preferences and the reality out there… compromise is necessary! In the end, to get income, you must “supply” (sell) something that someone else is willing to pay for, which is often a job: you sell your work effort, talents, skills, drive, willingness to learn the job and contribute to the employer and the employer is willing to pay for this. Sometimes it takes different forms. All is fine, as long as you are not lying to yourself. Action is the way out of anxiety If you really feel stuck in inertia, you need to find a way to shake yourself into massive action. Sometimes this requires a “big move” — volunteering overseas, moving to the jungle, whatever. But I am telling you now, and this is a bomb-proof truth of life: NOTHING will happen if you spin in your thoughts in your room and couch. If you just spin and spin and spin and do nothing, you will get “more of the same.” Some people secretly hope for some divine intervention or a major world shock or whatever, something that will “force them” out of their current situation. It won’t happen. People who constantly daydream and fantasize of “some life”, yet do nothing “concrete” to move in that direction will find that the forces of inertia are very strong. So get out of the house, meet positive people, put yourself out there, and make shit happen. One frequent problem is people stuck in inertia telling themselves “I know I want something ELSE than this current life, but I am not too sure what.” In that case, you need to work on getting clarity to build at least some kind of vision for a life worth living, in all important aspects of life. “Intelligence” is very over rated “Classic” intelligence in the form of deductive reasoning, logic, etc helps, but it is a FAR CRY from what action will bring to your life. I know a LOT of “smart” people who are spinning in total inertia in their deep and intelligent soul searching, while “down-to-earth-ordinary-Joes” are thriving due to action and drive. Intelligence helps, but it’s like a super-toned F1 race car: no gas, no go! Again, what it means to be “successful” is very personal, and has many angles: career, health, relationships, etc. I know LOTS of “successful” people career wise who are overweight, boring, have uninspiring lives and relationships, and are all around not particularly inspiring in any way. I have found that people who develop the skill of curiosity and a flexible mind thrive the most and find more joy and life satisfaction. Now suppose you have a strong tendency to inertia and self-doubt and general “laziness”, yet you know you need to take action — how to get out of this seemingly impossible dead end? SMALL STEPS… Make SHORT and REALISTIC lists of “things to do today”, and this can be as irrelevant as “do the laundry to the end and dry and fold and place neatly.” For people with issues of lack of follow-through, this is a big undertaking that takes time. Do it to the end, until the end result it done. Do NOT fill the list with a bunch of stuff to do, because you will get overwhelmed and you will freeze into inaction and feel like a loser, which will reinforce your subconscious inner dialog. What we need to do is learn the habit of autonomy and getting shit done, and that starts with seemingly “small” little things. Then expand the list. This will get you going into action, and THAT is the key. Try to get active and manage your anxiety with “healthy” activity: cooking, groceries, reading, sports, art, etc. Ponder, but don’t dwell in it too long… FB / Instagram / etc is not “healthy” and we all do it way to much, because we plug the boredom of life with these otherwise fine networks… do something else, something more engaging and meaningful. Click the heart if you liked. I will keep writing little tips like these, as I have noticed that my poor students often suffer from feeling lost and anxious and not knowing where to begin… Regards. Pascal Bedard www.yourpersonaleconomist.com
title_html: Lost and Struggling Students: What should you do with your life? Some tips and hope for you…
html:

Lost and Struggling Students: What should you do with your life? Some tips and hope for you…

Pascal Bedard
Jul 2, 2017

I see lots of “lost students” and many try to get guidance and help. I personally had many major life changes and made very hard choices in my life, and I helped a LOT of people and students change their lives quite dramatically. Some students “land” in university by default: they know they don’t want a minimum wage job forever, and they don’t see job options without a degree, so they “go to university” just because there are no clear options and they spend 3, 4, 5 years studying and hoping that things will clarify along the way.

The cycle of doom

We can “categorize” people in many ways and certainly many shades of grey exist, but I tend to “classify” students in 3 broad categories based on my experience:

  1. The ones who find something that makes them interested and curious enough to envision a job in that “sector.” Their vision for their life gives them drive, as they feel some purpose to what they are doing. They find self discipline, personal organization, curiosity, and energy, and they move on to fruitful studies, jobs, and lives.
  2. The ones who don’t care much about anything, but “cave into” reality: they accept that you gotta work and you can’t avoid it forever, and so they “do OK” but have many ups and downs and they can’t seem to find the drive and motivation that comes with a clear vision and purpose, so they have issues with regularity, self-discipline, follow-through, and recurring bouts of negative thoughts and feelings.
  3. The lost. They don’t really see themselves in anything “mainstream” and they can’t find the courage to “suck it up and work.” They are in denial and avoidance of reality, they find little interest in courses (but some may still perform very well), they ask “is this useful”, they may struggle in their courses and in their intimate relationships and friendships (which are often with other “lost individuals” who are less confronting for them, as they are just as lost as they are), and they suffer ongoing anxiety, inner turmoil, fear, and self-worth issues. They either get “official” anti depressants (rarely) OR they self-medicate with alcohol, drugs, sex, food, Netflix and social media binging, drama and instability, lots of “partying and social life” — anything that helps them escape the harsh reality of the income-jobs-and-responsibilities world.

From my extensive university teaching experience, I would say that the split is roughly balanced between these 3 groups, each representing about a third of all students. The ones in the first group generally do well and, more importantly, end up happy and positive young adults, with the normal ups and downs of life.

Others remain as lost as ever, and even more… and the anxiety increases as the end of the program approaches, because they don’t want to work in an office, they don’t see themselves anywhere, they don’t like technical stuff, and yet they gradually have no choice but to face reality: they need income and they can’t live off of mom and dad or student loans forever! They face “the question” with growing intensity. The post-bachelor’s degree blues sets in. The party is over. The freedom of managing your time essentially as you want is over (except for the 12 to 18 hours of actual class time, which they often skipped). The “real world.” Many have deep or minor depressions. The question… “What the hell should I do with my life?” Friends go on to various lives, realities, cities, and jobs, and the joy and magic of “student togetherness” withers away as time goes by.

Because we all need income to live life, pay mortgage / rent, food, travel, and so much more, many university grads find themselves ending university and faced with a harsh reality they were able to deny for their teens and during the roommate and Uni years: if you don’t get income from parents or the State or a spouse, you gotta work to get some… They enter a phase of existential crisis, as the years of avoidance near the end. Some go to graduate programs in master’s and phd, others don’t want to or don’t have the grades, yet they don’t seem to find a “spot to fit in” in terms of jobs. They feel alone, lost, and without a place in the world.

And so it goes. The positive ones who found a “study and career path” they feel motivated about move forward, while the ones who feel lost have deepening problems of anxiety and self worth. Some have parents that support them financially, which helps with the “real world” aspects of life (paying bills and stuff), but it does little in the way of bringing a sense of purpose and direction in life, which is key to some form of inner peace and life satisfaction.

The lost ones who have external financing even have another problem: they don’t even “have to” move their ass to work and do “something” with their time, so they risk stagnation and inertia, which breed anxiety and more inertia, self worth, and self-discipline issues. The initial lack of drive and motivation turns into an ingrained behavioural pattern, and the person launches into post-university life with a lack of drive, a lack purpose and vision, and increasing issues of inertia, laziness, and procrastination. Their self-worth sinks lower, which reinforces the inertia and lack of action that would pull them out of the rut. It can be a dark place.

Getting out of the rut

This rut is not specific to students and recent grads. Many people find themselves in such dynamics at one point or another between the start and the end of that great adventure we call life. Here are a few things you need to do to pull yourself out of that dark place…

Face reality

You must kill all forms of bullshit you are telling yourself and look at life and the world as they are, including yourself. “The system” may be imperfect and suck (I agree), but it is what it is and you won’t change it in any significant “macro way”, nor will I. You need to “do something” with your life, EVEN if you are financially supported. It is even more true if you have no significant external financial support. Autonomy and personal growth and key to self worth and life satisfaction.

This means you need to “move your ass” and do something other than social network surfing, video games, Netflix binging, and TV. Use your time to do things that make you learn and grow. In other words, you need to find “flow” in your life. This can be art, sports, working out, “causes”, whatever, but it has to be something that pulls you sufficiently to get you out of inertia. You also need to be nice with yourself and quit the inner dialogue about being a loser, as this will simply create what you are telling yourself, without being true. Also admit that life is not all rosy and fun, that boredom is very frequent and normal, that jobs are often not great, etc. You need to be nice with yourself but you must also stop feeling sorry for yourself.

Endless spinning on how jobs suck, how boring they are, how people are stupid, what you should of / could of / would have done is useless and perpetuates the layer of denial and illusion (i.e. bullshit) that are stopping you from becoming a more active and emotionally positive person that is lucid about what is and what can be done going forward.

Know yourself

This is a biggie and could be worth a whole book! You have to free yourself of the illusions imposed by yourself, family, or “society” about success and a meaningful life. I am personally a bit fed up with blog posts on “productivity” and “achievement” and all that pop psy stuff. Not that it’s not true or useful — it is. But before you start to attack your issues of lack of drive and direction, you need to get clear on what you want and what you don’t, what you can and what you can’t realistically do. Once you have a clear and bs-free picture of who you are, THEN you will gradually be able to look into becoming “productive and creative” and all that great stuff.

If you don’t want to work in the corporate world, relax, it’s FINE — many people are like that, including most of your profs! You must get clear on 1) who you are, 2) what you can “reasonably tolerate” in a job or occupation (there are always cons — not just “pros”), what you can’t do or tolerate due to personality, attention span, personal initiative, risk tolerance, and more.

This must be an all-around and deep introspection into your basic tendencies, talents, natural interests, strengths, and weaknesses. It is very important that this picture be done with brutal honesty, so avoid asking friends who always avoid tough or awkward discussions. There is NO “wrong” picture of who you are, but don’t forget that you can’t simply come to the conclusion that you don’t want to work or do anything, unless you have infinite financial support, but EVEN THEN I very strongly suggest you do “something” with your life, because you will end up miserable, bored, and the endless freedom and leisure will start to feel hollow as the years go by…

Explore income opportunities

Explore ALL possibilities. Look at all titles of the BLS jobs list and imagine what it’s like. Then expand your imagination into jobs, occupations, and careers that may not be there. There are lots. You can reinvent yourself totally many times, at ANY age. I did it and so can you. Don’t forget that you want to do “something” with your time and your life. If you don’t need money, then explore what you can do that would bring “meaning” to your weeks and months. The possibilities are endless and they need not involve helping others. Just explore what you feel good about when you visualize that “life setup” as vividly and realistically as possible. Some people like to climb full time, others like to work like crazy — it’s all fine, as long as it aligns at least in large part with what you “are” fundamentally and a life that brings meaning to your days and makes you get out of bed.

Match income opportunities with who you are (as much as possible)

Once you have done proper introspection and explored the opportunities for income and occupations, try to match the realities of yourself (talents, strengths, weaknesses, etc) with the jobs or occupations. For example, if you value income and job security, don’t look into self employment. If you can’t develop self discipline and personal initiative, perhaps it will be hard to do projects on your own, so keep it in mind.

Again, don’t overdo it: NO occupation or job is totally “perfect”! Most people “suck it up” at least a bit, and that’s ok, it’s called reality. Just avoid landing in a life and job path that is totally disconnected from who you are, because you will be miserable and will probably suffer mentally (depression) or physically due to psychosomatic symptoms, or both. Even if I gave you 1 million dollars per year to chill out, you would eventually find it lacking purpose, because humans seek meaning from this crazy world and mysterious life. You must find a “reasonable” compromise between your personality and general characteristics and preferences and the reality out there… compromise is necessary!

In the end, to get income, you must “supply” (sell) something that someone else is willing to pay for, which is often a job: you sell your work effort, talents, skills, drive, willingness to learn the job and contribute to the employer and the employer is willing to pay for this. Sometimes it takes different forms. All is fine, as long as you are not lying to yourself.

Action is the way out of anxiety

If you really feel stuck in inertia, you need to find a way to shake yourself into massive action. Sometimes this requires a “big move” — volunteering overseas, moving to the jungle, whatever. But I am telling you now, and this is a bomb-proof truth of life: NOTHING will happen if you spin in your thoughts in your room and couch. If you just spin and spin and spin and do nothing, you will get “more of the same.” Some people secretly hope for some divine intervention or a major world shock or whatever, something that will “force them” out of their current situation. It won’t happen. People who constantly daydream and fantasize of “some life”, yet do nothing “concrete” to move in that direction will find that the forces of inertia are very strong. So get out of the house, meet positive people, put yourself out there, and make shit happen. One frequent problem is people stuck in inertia telling themselves “I know I want something ELSE than this current life, but I am not too sure what.” In that case, you need to work on getting clarity to build at least some kind of vision for a life worth living, in all important aspects of life.

“Intelligence” is very over rated

“Classic” intelligence in the form of deductive reasoning, logic, etc helps, but it is a FAR CRY from what action will bring to your life. I know a LOT of “smart” people who are spinning in total inertia in their deep and intelligent soul searching, while “down-to-earth-ordinary-Joes” are thriving due to action and drive. Intelligence helps, but it’s like a super-toned F1 race car: no gas, no go! Again, what it means to be “successful” is very personal, and has many angles: career, health, relationships, etc. I know LOTS of “successful” people career wise who are overweight, boring, have uninspiring lives and relationships, and are all around not particularly inspiring in any way. I have found that people who develop the skill of curiosity and a flexible mind thrive the most and find more joy and life satisfaction.

Now suppose you have a strong tendency to inertia and self-doubt and general “laziness”, yet you know you need to take action — how to get out of this seemingly impossible dead end? SMALL STEPS… Make SHORT and REALISTIC lists of “things to do today”, and this can be as irrelevant as “do the laundry to the end and dry and fold and place neatly.” For people with issues of lack of follow-through, this is a big undertaking that takes time. Do it to the end, until the end result it done. Do NOT fill the list with a bunch of stuff to do, because you will get overwhelmed and you will freeze into inaction and feel like a loser, which will reinforce your subconscious inner dialog. What we need to do is learn the habit of autonomy and getting shit done, and that starts with seemingly “small” little things. Then expand the list.

This will get you going into action, and THAT is the key. Try to get active and manage your anxiety with “healthy” activity: cooking, groceries, reading, sports, art, etc. Ponder, but don’t dwell in it too long… FB / Instagram / etc is not “healthy” and we all do it way to much, because we plug the boredom of life with these otherwise fine networks… do something else, something more engaging and meaningful. Click the heart if you liked.

I will keep writing little tips like these, as I have noticed that my poor students often suffer from feeling lost and anxious and not knowing where to begin… Regards.

Pascal Bedard

title: Lost and Struggling Students: What should you do with your life? Some tips and hope for you…
content_html:
Lost and Struggling Students: What should you do with your life? Some tips and hope for you…

Pascal Bedard
Jul 2, 2017

I see lots of “lost students” and many try to get guidance and help. I personally had many major life changes and made very hard choices in my life, and I helped a LOT of people and students change their lives quite dramatically. Some students “land” in university by default: they know they don’t want a minimum wage job forever, and they don’t see job options without a degree, so they “go to university” just because there are no clear options and they spend 3, 4, 5 years studying and hoping that things will clarify along the way.

The cycle of doom

We can “categorize” people in many ways and certainly many shades of grey exist, but I tend to “classify” students in 3 broad categories based on my experience:

  1. The ones who find something that makes them interested and curious enough to envision a job in that “sector.” Their vision for their life gives them drive, as they feel some purpose to what they are doing. They find self discipline, personal organization, curiosity, and energy, and they move on to fruitful studies, jobs, and lives.
  2. The ones who don’t care much about anything, but “cave into” reality: they accept that you gotta work and you can’t avoid it forever, and so they “do OK” but have many ups and downs and they can’t seem to find the drive and motivation that comes with a clear vision and purpose, so they have issues with regularity, self-discipline, follow-through, and recurring bouts of negative thoughts and feelings.
  3. The lost. They don’t really see themselves in anything “mainstream” and they can’t find the courage to “suck it up and work.” They are in denial and avoidance of reality, they find little interest in courses (but some may still perform very well), they ask “is this useful”, they may struggle in their courses and in their intimate relationships and friendships (which are often with other “lost individuals” who are less confronting for them, as they are just as lost as they are), and they suffer ongoing anxiety, inner turmoil, fear, and self-worth issues. They either get “official” anti depressants (rarely) OR they self-medicate with alcohol, drugs, sex, food, Netflix and social media binging, drama and instability, lots of “partying and social life” — anything that helps them escape the harsh reality of the income-jobs-and-responsibilities world.

From my extensive university teaching experience, I would say that the split is roughly balanced between these 3 groups, each representing about a third of all students. The ones in the first group generally do well and, more importantly, end up happy and positive young adults, with the normal ups and downs of life.

Others remain as lost as ever, and even more… and the anxiety increases as the end of the program approaches, because they don’t want to work in an office, they don’t see themselves anywhere, they don’t like technical stuff, and yet they gradually have no choice but to face reality: they need income and they can’t live off of mom and dad or student loans forever! They face “the question” with growing intensity. The post-bachelor’s degree blues sets in. The party is over. The freedom of managing your time essentially as you want is over (except for the 12 to 18 hours of actual class time, which they often skipped). The “real world.” Many have deep or minor depressions. The question… “What the hell should I do with my life?” Friends go on to various lives, realities, cities, and jobs, and the joy and magic of “student togetherness” withers away as time goes by.

Because we all need income to live life, pay mortgage / rent, food, travel, and so much more, many university grads find themselves ending university and faced with a harsh reality they were able to deny for their teens and during the roommate and Uni years: if you don’t get income from parents or the State or a spouse, you gotta work to get some… They enter a phase of existential crisis, as the years of avoidance near the end. Some go to graduate programs in master’s and phd, others don’t want to or don’t have the grades, yet they don’t seem to find a “spot to fit in” in terms of jobs. They feel alone, lost, and without a place in the world.

And so it goes. The positive ones who found a “study and career path” they feel motivated about move forward, while the ones who feel lost have deepening problems of anxiety and self worth. Some have parents that support them financially, which helps with the “real world” aspects of life (paying bills and stuff), but it does little in the way of bringing a sense of purpose and direction in life, which is key to some form of inner peace and life satisfaction.

The lost ones who have external financing even have another problem: they don’t even “have to” move their ass to work and do “something” with their time, so they risk stagnation and inertia, which breed anxiety and more inertia, self worth, and self-discipline issues. The initial lack of drive and motivation turns into an ingrained behavioural pattern, and the person launches into post-university life with a lack of drive, a lack purpose and vision, and increasing issues of inertia, laziness, and procrastination. Their self-worth sinks lower, which reinforces the inertia and lack of action that would pull them out of the rut. It can be a dark place.

Getting out of the rut

This rut is not specific to students and recent grads. Many people find themselves in such dynamics at one point or another between the start and the end of that great adventure we call life. Here are a few things you need to do to pull yourself out of that dark place…

Face reality

You must kill all forms of bullshit you are telling yourself and look at life and the world as they are, including yourself. “The system” may be imperfect and suck (I agree), but it is what it is and you won’t change it in any significant “macro way”, nor will I. You need to “do something” with your life, EVEN if you are financially supported. It is even more true if you have no significant external financial support. Autonomy and personal growth and key to self worth and life satisfaction.

This means you need to “move your ass” and do something other than social network surfing, video games, Netflix binging, and TV. Use your time to do things that make you learn and grow. In other words, you need to find “flow” in your life. This can be art, sports, working out, “causes”, whatever, but it has to be something that pulls you sufficiently to get you out of inertia. You also need to be nice with yourself and quit the inner dialogue about being a loser, as this will simply create what you are telling yourself, without being true. Also admit that life is not all rosy and fun, that boredom is very frequent and normal, that jobs are often not great, etc. You need to be nice with yourself but you must also stop feeling sorry for yourself.

Endless spinning on how jobs suck, how boring they are, how people are stupid, what you should of / could of / would have done is useless and perpetuates the layer of denial and illusion (i.e. bullshit) that are stopping you from becoming a more active and emotionally positive person that is lucid about what is and what can be done going forward.

Know yourself

This is a biggie and could be worth a whole book! You have to free yourself of the illusions imposed by yourself, family, or “society” about success and a meaningful life. I am personally a bit fed up with blog posts on “productivity” and “achievement” and all that pop psy stuff. Not that it’s not true or useful — it is. But before you start to attack your issues of lack of drive and direction, you need to get clear on what you want and what you don’t, what you can and what you can’t realistically do. Once you have a clear and bs-free picture of who you are, THEN you will gradually be able to look into becoming “productive and creative” and all that great stuff.

If you don’t want to work in the corporate world, relax, it’s FINE — many people are like that, including most of your profs! You must get clear on 1) who you are, 2) what you can “reasonably tolerate” in a job or occupation (there are always cons — not just “pros”), what you can’t do or tolerate due to personality, attention span, personal initiative, risk tolerance, and more.

This must be an all-around and deep introspection into your basic tendencies, talents, natural interests, strengths, and weaknesses. It is very important that this picture be done with brutal honesty, so avoid asking friends who always avoid tough or awkward discussions. There is NO “wrong” picture of who you are, but don’t forget that you can’t simply come to the conclusion that you don’t want to work or do anything, unless you have infinite financial support, but EVEN THEN I very strongly suggest you do “something” with your life, because you will end up miserable, bored, and the endless freedom and leisure will start to feel hollow as the years go by…

Explore income opportunities

Explore ALL possibilities. Look at all titles of the BLS jobs list and imagine what it’s like. Then expand your imagination into jobs, occupations, and careers that may not be there. There are lots. You can reinvent yourself totally many times, at ANY age. I did it and so can you. Don’t forget that you want to do “something” with your time and your life. If you don’t need money, then explore what you can do that would bring “meaning” to your weeks and months. The possibilities are endless and they need not involve helping others. Just explore what you feel good about when you visualize that “life setup” as vividly and realistically as possible. Some people like to climb full time, others like to work like crazy — it’s all fine, as long as it aligns at least in large part with what you “are” fundamentally and a life that brings meaning to your days and makes you get out of bed.

Match income opportunities with who you are (as much as possible)

Once you have done proper introspection and explored the opportunities for income and occupations, try to match the realities of yourself (talents, strengths, weaknesses, etc) with the jobs or occupations. For example, if you value income and job security, don’t look into self employment. If you can’t develop self discipline and personal initiative, perhaps it will be hard to do projects on your own, so keep it in mind.

Again, don’t overdo it: NO occupation or job is totally “perfect”! Most people “suck it up” at least a bit, and that’s ok, it’s called reality. Just avoid landing in a life and job path that is totally disconnected from who you are, because you will be miserable and will probably suffer mentally (depression) or physically due to psychosomatic symptoms, or both. Even if I gave you 1 million dollars per year to chill out, you would eventually find it lacking purpose, because humans seek meaning from this crazy world and mysterious life. You must find a “reasonable” compromise between your personality and general characteristics and preferences and the reality out there… compromise is necessary!

In the end, to get income, you must “supply” (sell) something that someone else is willing to pay for, which is often a job: you sell your work effort, talents, skills, drive, willingness to learn the job and contribute to the employer and the employer is willing to pay for this. Sometimes it takes different forms. All is fine, as long as you are not lying to yourself.

Action is the way out of anxiety

If you really feel stuck in inertia, you need to find a way to shake yourself into massive action. Sometimes this requires a “big move” — volunteering overseas, moving to the jungle, whatever. But I am telling you now, and this is a bomb-proof truth of life: NOTHING will happen if you spin in your thoughts in your room and couch. If you just spin and spin and spin and do nothing, you will get “more of the same.” Some people secretly hope for some divine intervention or a major world shock or whatever, something that will “force them” out of their current situation. It won’t happen. People who constantly daydream and fantasize of “some life”, yet do nothing “concrete” to move in that direction will find that the forces of inertia are very strong. So get out of the house, meet positive people, put yourself out there, and make shit happen. One frequent problem is people stuck in inertia telling themselves “I know I want something ELSE than this current life, but I am not too sure what.” In that case, you need to work on getting clarity to build at least some kind of vision for a life worth living, in all important aspects of life.

“Intelligence” is very over rated

“Classic” intelligence in the form of deductive reasoning, logic, etc helps, but it is a FAR CRY from what action will bring to your life. I know a LOT of “smart” people who are spinning in total inertia in their deep and intelligent soul searching, while “down-to-earth-ordinary-Joes” are thriving due to action and drive. Intelligence helps, but it’s like a super-toned F1 race car: no gas, no go! Again, what it means to be “successful” is very personal, and has many angles: career, health, relationships, etc. I know LOTS of “successful” people career wise who are overweight, boring, have uninspiring lives and relationships, and are all around not particularly inspiring in any way. I have found that people who develop the skill of curiosity and a flexible mind thrive the most and find more joy and life satisfaction.

Now suppose you have a strong tendency to inertia and self-doubt and general “laziness”, yet you know you need to take action — how to get out of this seemingly impossible dead end? SMALL STEPS… Make SHORT and REALISTIC lists of “things to do today”, and this can be as irrelevant as “do the laundry to the end and dry and fold and place neatly.” For people with issues of lack of follow-through, this is a big undertaking that takes time. Do it to the end, until the end result it done. Do NOT fill the list with a bunch of stuff to do, because you will get overwhelmed and you will freeze into inaction and feel like a loser, which will reinforce your subconscious inner dialog. What we need to do is learn the habit of autonomy and getting shit done, and that starts with seemingly “small” little things. Then expand the list.

This will get you going into action, and THAT is the key. Try to get active and manage your anxiety with “healthy” activity: cooking, groceries, reading, sports, art, etc. Ponder, but don’t dwell in it too long… FB / Instagram / etc is not “healthy” and we all do it way to much, because we plug the boredom of life with these otherwise fine networks… do something else, something more engaging and meaningful. Click the heart if you liked.

I will keep writing little tips like these, as I have noticed that my poor students often suffer from feeling lost and anxious and not knowing where to begin… Regards.

Pascal Bedard

www.yourpersonaleconomist.com
